title: Administration Building (New)
date_notes: Begun in 1907, first unit completed in 1909.
use_history: Administrative offices, Letters & Science/Business classrooms, University computer center, auditorium, also housed the library until 1957
additions: Built in four units, the original (1909), North wing (1912), South wing (1920) extended 1936 for library expansion $110,000. Annex constructed 1950. 1960 remodeling after library construction $115,168; Elevator tower added ca. 2000
architect: Central Wing, 1909 - John E. Tourtellotte (Boise), North Wing, 1913 - Preusse and Zittel (Spokane), South Wing, ca. 1920 - Curtis Richardson (Lewiston), South Wing Extension, 1937 - unknown.
description: Concrete base, red brick facing with buff colored Boise sandstone trim, college Gothic style, three stories, U shaped, 109,824 square feet. Listed on National Register of Historic Places.
location_description: Center of main quadrangle facing east 851 Campus Drive
cost_notes: Unit 1, $140,000; unit 2, $75,000; unit 3, $90,000 state appropriations; unit 4 $110,769 funded by student fees
sources: Cards, UG 44, Morton, Beacon, UG 12 (2304), IHS 134, Facilities Architecture Drawing Archives

title: Administration Building (Old)
use_history: Administrative offices and classroom building
additions: East wing completed in 1899; auditorium and third floor completed 1900; west wing completed in 1902
description: Four stories, red brick, 180' x 122', central portion and two wings, 163' tower.
location_description: On site of present administration building, facing N.E. instead of due east
sources: Cards, UG 44, Beacon, Petersen, Facilities Architecture Drawing Archives

title: Agricultural Engineering Building (JW Martin)
use_history: Ag engineering classrooms and labs
description: one floor, tilt-up concrete; long and narrow; 400 feet long, 30,000 square feet; some ceilings as high as 18 feet
location_description: 6th street and Perimeter Drive
cost_notes: $1.8 million (State and University each provided half)

title: Agricultural Engineering Laboratory
standing_notes: Attached to the original steam plant which was built in 1909. Torn down in 1998 to make way for the Idaho Commons (Now the ISUB). Demolished 1998 for Idaho Commons
name_history: Agricultural Engineering Laboratory 1951-1986; Art and Architecture Annex 1986-1998
use_history: Originally constructed as heating plant; When new heating plant was constructed in 1927 it became maintenance shop; in 1949 maintenance shops were moved and the building was renovated for Agricultural Engineering Laboratory in 1950 and 1951
additions: Renovated in 1950-1951. Became Art and Architecture Annex in 1986 upon completion of new Agricultural Engineering Building; demolished 1998 for Idaho Commons
description: Brick, with basement and two floors, 15,330 square feet
location_description: NW corner University Avenue and Line Street

title: Engineering Shops
standing_notes: Built in 1909, abandoned by Idaho Harvester company in 1918, purchased by UI in 1923. Demolished 1950-1960.
name_history: Engineering Shops or Engineering Laboratories
use_history: Was Idaho Harvester Comapny's building from 1909 to about 1918. Used by UI from 1923 to 1950s or 1960s to house the agricultural engineering and the mechanical engineering departments. Current site of Rosauers Supermarket since 1976.
location_description: Corner of D Street and N. Main Street
sources: Cards, UG 44, Morton, UG 12 Bx 80 File 2276

title: Agricultural Science Building
standing_notes: Completed in 1951.  Addition: 1974 - Bellamy, Bratvold & Carpenter.
name_history: Iddings Agricultural Science Building
naming_notes: Renamed Iddings Agricultural Science Building in 1974 for E.J. Iddings, Dean of Agricultural Sciences 1915-1946.
use_history: Classrooms, teaching labs; research labs; faculty and administrative offices
additions: 1971. 57,000 sq. ft. addition at a cost of $1,967,000, Bellamy, Bratvold & Carpenter (Coeur d'Alene) architects.
description: Reinforced concrete, brick veneer, basement and three floors, 169' x 52', flat roof, 54,443 square feet
location_description: Rayburn Avenue between Idaho Avenue and Sixth Street 606 Rayburn St
sources: Cards, UG 44, Morton, Facilities Architecture Drawing Archives

title: Agriculture Biotechnology Building and Laboratory
use_history: 80 Percent of the Building House Molecular-based Research Programs involving Plants, Livestock and Microorganisms,20 Percent of the Building Consist Faculty Offices,Conference Rooms and Interaction Space.
architect: Ellis-Feeney Architects of Lewiston and SRG Architects (Portland)
description: Three Floor,45.000-Squar-foot Brick Building
location_description: Rayburn and 6th street

title: Albertson Building
use_history: Remodeled and enlarged Administration Annex (1950; Whitehouse, Price, DeNeff, Architects (Spokane); Reinforced concrete and brick facing; 134' x 66', two floors and basement, flat roof; 25,254 square feet; $343,360; Administrative offices; controller, registrar, admissions) to house College of Business and Economics first building to be funded entirely by private gifts; contains full-service deli and campus bookstore
architect: Design West Architects, Gordon Walker, Architect; Yost Grube Hall Architecture; Swank Enterprises, General Contractor
location_description: West side of Administration building 875 Campus Drive
sources: Facilities Website, Dedication Plaques and Stones Images

title: Aquaculture Institute and Poultry Hill Warehouse
architect: Constructed by UI Department of Buildings and Grounds
location_description: 799 Poultry Hill Way

title: Archie Phinney Hall
standing_notes: Original Construction: 1938 - Hugh Richardson; Whitehouse & Price. Addition: 1999 (elevator tower).
name_history: Originally named Chrisman Hall, briefly called Faculty Office Complex West
naming_notes: Renamed Archie Phinney Hall in 1987 in honor of Nez Perce anthropologist Archie Phinney.
use_history: Men's dormitory, later Sociology-Anthropology museum and department offices; misc. faculty offices.
additions: Elevator tower addition - 1999
description: 4-story collegiate gothic brick building with basement.  L-shaped plan. Reinforced concrete and brick, gable roof, stone coated metal shingles,  each wing about 98' x 30'.
location_description: 701 S Line Street

title: Armory (Old)
name_history: Also known as The Annex
use_history: Also housed agriculture department and gymnasium
description: Wooden building, about 50' x 125', one story and basement in front, two stories in rear
location_description: About 100' behind the old Administration Building

title: Art and Architecture Building
name_history: Metallurgical Building; Mines Building; Psychology Building; Art and Architecture
use_history: Originally a metallurgical laboratory used for student work and metallurgical research. Became Mines building in 1950. Ca. 1961 became Psychology Building housing classrooms, offices and laboratories. Art & Architecture ca. 2001
additions: Renovated and completely remodelled by adding three floors to the center of the building in 1949-1950; Elevator tower added 1998
description: Wood frame with red pressed brick veneer walls, three stories, gable roof with cedar shingles. 84' x 96'. Originally built as a large scale concentrator
location_description: Pine near University Ave.

title: Art and Architecture East
architect: Renovated for classrooms by UI Department of Buildings and Grounds
description: Former Carpet Mill building
location_description: College Avenue 327 College Ave

title: Art and Architecture Interior Design
name_history: Navy Building #2, 1942-1945; Faculty Club, 1945-1971; Satellite Sub, 1971-2000; Art & Architecture Annex
use_history: Originally Navy Building #2, Became Faculty Club in 1945, food service; College of Art & Architecture, Interior Design Dept in 2000-
description: One story and basement, wood frame and siding, 52' x 32'
location_description: Idaho Ave. and Pine Street

title: Art and Architecture North
name_history: Originally named Art and Architecture Building. "North" was added when the old gym was remodeled in 1976 and named Art and Architecture South
use_history: Art and Architecture administrative offices; computer lab; studios, faculty offices
description: Red brick, 4 floors, front is glass.
location_description: S.W. corner University Avenue and Line Street 951 University Ave

title: Art and Architecture South
name_history: Gymnasium, Women's Gymnasium, Art and Architecture South
use_history: Originally constructed as the university's second gymnasium and armory; became the Women's gym when Memorial Gym was completed in 1928. Remodeled for art and architecture studios and classrooms in 1976. Listed on National Register of Historic Places
description: Granite foundation, red brick facing, basement and two floors, gable roof; 64' x 129'
location_description: Line Street, N.W. of Administration Building. 951 Campus Dr

title: Art Building
standing_notes: Torn down in 1965 and replaced by Art and Architecture North
name_history: Lewis Court; Art Building
use_history: Formerly known as Lewis Court, built as annex to the Women's Gym (then Men's gym) and used for winter military drill and recreation. Was men's dormitory during 1937-1938. Became Art and Architecture building in 1938
additions: Renovated in 1945
description: Wood frame, one story, 60' x 80' with cinder floor
location_description: West side of quadrangle (SW corner of Line and University Ave.)

title: Bartley Cottage
use_history: Acquired in 1921 and used as a girl's dormitory until 1929 when it became a music studio.
description: Two story, wooden frame and siding, gable roof, wood shingles
location_description: SW of Ridenbaugh Hall on Nez Perce west of Center Cottage

title: Blake House
naming_notes: Originally, named for Mrs. Ethel Steel, Board of Regents, 1933-1946, a leader in the movement to provide cooperative dormitories at the U of I.
use_history: Cooperative dormitory for 58 girls; replaced Ridenbaugh Hall as a residence. The dormitory has moved several time since then.
architect: Hugh Richardson (Lewiston); General contractor, Commercial Builders (Moscow)
description: Wood frame with brick ornament, flat roof; basement and three floors, 11,116 sq. feet
location_description: Blake Street

title: Bookstore
use_history: Academic and general book supply and clothing sales; campus station of U.S. Post Office
architect: Moritz Kundig of Northwest Architectural Co. (Spokane)
description: Gray concrete masonry, one story; 15,000 sq. ft.
location_description: Deakin Avenue across from SUB 706/704 Deakin Ave

title: Brink and Phinney Halls
name_history: Willis Sweet Hall; later called Faculty Office Complex East; Chrisman Hall; Faculty Office Complex West
naming_notes: Willis Sweet Hall named after one of the UI's founders and member of the Board of Regents, 1889-1893; later called Faculty Office Complex East. Renamed Carol Ryrie Brink Hall in the early 1980s in honor of UI alumna and prominent author. Chrisman Hall, named after General Edward Chrisman. Later referred to as Faculty Office Complex West. Renamed Archie Phinney Hall in early 1980s
use_history: Brink: Originally a men's dorm housing 200. Currently houses placement center; math/statistics/English departments, miscellaneous faculty and grad offices. Phinney: Men's dormitory, later Sociology-Anthropology museum and department offices; misc. faculty offices
additions: Elevator towers added to both in 1999
description: Brink: Reinforced concrete, red fireproof brick, trimmed with Boise Sandstone. Gable roof, composition shingles, five floors, front 178' long, wings 81' and 129' long respectively, each wing about 29' wide. Phinney: Four floors and basement, reinforced concrete and brick, gable roof, wood shingles, each wing about 98' x 30'
location_description: Line Street and Idaho Avenue 801 & 701 S. Line St

title: Buchanan Engineering Laboratory
naming_notes: Named for Jesse E. Buchanan, UI alumnus, faculty and President from 1946-1954
use_history: Engineering classrooms, teaching and research labs; faculty and grad offices
description: 3 story, reinforced concrete; 80,000 sq. ft.
location_description: 6th Street 607 Urquhart Ave

title: Campus Christian Center
use_history: Campus Christian Center, Moscow Food Coop satellite cafe.

title: Campus Club (1938-1958)
use_history: Men's dormitory
description: Wooden frame, siding and shingles, one story, gable roof.
location_description: Sixth Street

title: Campus Landmarks
location_description: NE corner of Railroad and Sweet

title: Campus Landscapes
location_description: Moscow. Idaho

title: Carol Ryrie Brink
standing_notes: Original Construction: 1936 - Hugh Richardson; Whitehouse & Price. Addition: 1999 (elevator tower).
name_history: Willis Sweet Hall; later called Faculty Office Complex East
naming_notes: Willis Sweet Hall named after one of the UI's founders and member of the Board of Regents, 1889-1893; later called Faculty Office Complex East. Renamed Carol Ryrie Brink Hall in 1982 in honor of UI alumna and prominent author.
use_history: Originally a men's dorm housing 200. Currently houses placement center; math/statistics/English departments, miscellaneous faculty and grad offices.
additions: Elevator towers added in 1999.
description: Reinforced concrete, red fireproof brick, trimmed with Boise Sandstone. Gable roof, composition shingles, five floors, front 178' long, wings 81' and 129' long respectively, each wing about 29' wide.
location_description: Line Street and Idaho Avenue 801 & 701 S. Line St

title: Cedar Hall
standing_notes: Torn down December 1957 due to poor condition
use_history: Infirmary, Phi Delta fraternity house, men's living group, music recital hall
description: Two floors and basement, wood frame, siding and shingles, gable roof
location_description: SE corner of Ash and Idaho Ave.

title: Center Cottage
use_history: Home of local sorority Omega Alpha, February 1926 - ?; Housed students at first; later used for music studio
location_description: SW corner of Blake and Nez Perce

title: Commons
use_history: Originally that Campus Classroom Center, it now houses the ASUI Student Government, Student Organizations, Classrooms,Computer Lab,Retail Outlets, Foodcourt, and Copy center. In 2005, The Teaching and Learning Center was built and attached to its west side.
architect: Yost Grube Architects and Design West Architects (Pullman)
description: 78.000 Squar-foot Facility
location_description: Idaho Avenue & Line Street 875 S. Line St

title: Craig Cottage
use_history: Acquired in 1930, served for many years as stenographic center and infirmary quarters. Later used as office space for Ag. Economics.
description: One story, frame building
location_description: Sixth Street between Urquhart and Line; in 1942 it was moved to a position east of Entomology Building (Line & 7th St.) to make room for Kirtley #1.

title: Crest Cottage
use_history: Acquired in 1922; formerly old Phi Delt house; in 1923 Chi Beta Epsilon sorority house. Part of old infirmary in 1927; also part of Triangle Club.
location_description: Idaho and Ash

title: Dairy Science Building
name_history: Dairy Building, 1918-1945; Agronomy Building, 1945-1951; Communications Building, 1951-
use_history: Originally built as Dairy Science Building; converted to Agronomy building in 1945. Became Communication Building when Agriculture Science was completed in 1951; demolished 1998 for Idaho Commons
additions: Interior completely rebuilt in 1947 52,591 square feet
description: Brick, basement and two stories, flat roof
location_description: SW corner of Line Street and Idaho Avenue

title: Dan O'Brien Track and Field Complex
location_description: West of Kibbie Dome

title: Day Care Center
name_history: Day Care Center; South Hill Apartment
use_history: Child care services for 30 children; family housing unit
additions: Renovated in 1993 and turned into 2 and 3 bedroom apartments
architect: Designed by Mark Samuelson, UI Sophomore architecture student; constructed by Boise Cascade
description: 2 story, wood
location_description: Deakin Street (South Hill housing complex)

title: Drama Annex
name_history: Temporary Classroom Building #5, Alumni Center, Audio-Visual, Drama Annex, Theatre Arts Annex; Women's Center
use_history: Originally mailing center; in 1949 it became the Alumni Center; Audio Visual moved into it February 1951; Drama Annex or Theatre Arts Annex; Architecture Studio & 2 Architecture Faculty Offices; Women's Center (2000-? )
architect: Former Army hospital, moved to campus 1946-1947
description: One story frame, gable, composition shingles, wood siding, 25' x 50"
location_description: Pine Street and University Ave.

title: Education Building
use_history: Construction April 1967-Dec. 1968; occupied 1969. Education administrative offices; library; classrooms; labs; faculty and grad offices
description: Concrete foundation, Concrete & brick walls, 5 floors; also a separate round lecture hall called a kiva
location_description: West of Administration Building 921 Campus Dr

title: Elmwood Apartments
description: Private apartment house, purchased for graduate student housing
location_description: 7th Street & Blake 627 Elm St

title: Engineering and Physics Building
naming_notes: Physics floor named for Leonard Halland, UI alumnus and manager of physics lab 1920-1940 and contributor to UI Foundation
use_history: Ground breaking October 1993, occupation fall 1995. National Center for Advanced Transportation Technology, Engineering outreach program, Mechanical and agricultural engineering classrooms, laboratories, offices, and physics department
location_description: 7th street, N.E. of McClure Hall 691 Ash St.
sources: Register (Aug. 23, 1993), Argonaut, VF, Facilities Architecture Drawing Archives

title: Engineering Building (Old)
standing_notes: Razed Summer 1951 due to unsafe conditions. Replaced by Home Economic Building
name_history: Applied Science Building; School of Mines; Engineering Building
use_history: Originally Applied Science Building; then used by School of Mines; In 1906 housed engineering classrooms and labs.
description: Brick, basement and three floors, 60' x 108', 20,982 sq. ft.
location_description: South side of quadrangle

title: Farm House
name_history: ca.1971 became Farm House
naming_notes: Named for Permeal French, Dean of Women, 1908-1936; ca.1971 became Farm House, a men's fraternity
use_history: Women's housing; men's housing
architect: Hugh Richardson (Lewiston); Contractors: Hanson & Parr Construction Co. of Spokane
description: Wood frame with brick and transite veneer, one story lounge, kitchen and dining area and two story dormitory providing housing for 55-60 students, 12,119 sq. ft.
location_description: Southwest corner of Blake Avenue and Nez Perce, south of Ridenbaugh Hall (on the site of Center Cottage) 1101 Blake Ave
cost_notes: $130,000 (bonds, to be paid by income from room rentals) Total cost $170,842

title: Field House
description: Heavy timber construction and aluminum sheeting, concrete foundation, no floor, unsupported roof, 100' x 175'
location_description: SW end of McLean Field

title: Food Science Building
name_history: Dairy Science Building; Food Research Center; Food Science Building
use_history: Dairy science classrooms and labs; currently fermentation/bacteriology/ WAMI research and teaching labs; classrooms
description: Reinforced concrete basement with brick walls, 94' x 92', basement and two floors, flat roof, 14,995 sq. ft.
location_description: NE corner Idaho Ave and Line Street 860 W. Idaho Ave

title: Forestry Laboratory
name_history: Forestry Laboratory, Industrial Arts Building following 1952 fire, Graduate Art Studio (GAS House), 1970-1972
use_history: Moved from S.E. corner of Sixth and Line Streets to Urquhart Street; to Line St. north of 6th (1950), to make room for Engineering Building. Combined with Pea Weevil Research Laboratory building. Later Industrial Arts, then Graduate Art Studio
architect: Constructed by UI Department of Buildings and Grounds
description: One story wood frame and concrete, cedar lap siding, cedar shingles, gable roof, 98' x 30'
location_description: Line Street

title: Forney Hall
name_history: Forney Hall; Continuing Education Building
naming_notes: Named for Mary E. Forney of Moscow, wife of first acting president of the University, James E. Forney. Forney Hall, Continuing Education Building
use_history: Women's dormitory for 120 women, currently used for offices, institutes and guest residence center
additions: Remodeled in 1971 with University offices on ground floor and students apartments on upper floors
description: Three story reinforced concrete, mission brick, gable roof with wooden shingles. Basement and sub-basement, collegiate Gothic style, 65' x 140'
location_description: Blake Ave. 1210 Blake Ave (Continuing Ed. Bldg.)
cost_notes: $100,000 (Financed by U of I Building Association composed of Moscow business men and leased to U of I. Indebtedness later paid off.

title: GAS (Graduate Art Studio) House
name_history: Also known as Engineering Annex; Engineering Shop Building; later (ca. 1971) Graduate Art Studio (GAS House)
use_history: Engineering shop and testing, later studios for graduate art students
description: Reinforced concrete with brick veneer, basement and two floors, 60' x 108'. Annex is wood frame siding and shingles, gable roof; 11,505 sq. ft.
location_description: South of Home Economics Building 670 Nez Perce Drive

title: Gault-Upham Halls
standing_notes: Demolished 2003 for phase two of Living Learning Community
naming_notes: Named for Franklin B. Gault, University President, 1892-1898 and Alfred Horatio Upham, University President, 1920-1928
use_history: Men's dormitory housing up to 344 students
additions: Gault was extensively damaged by an arson fire October 19, 1956 and renovated in 1957
architect: Hugh Richardson, (Lewiston); major contractor Commercial Builders (Moscow).
description: Three stories and basement, reinforced concrete structural frame encased in brick, flat roof. Built to replace Pine Hall. Upham is West dormitory and Gault the East. Common central kitchen, but each dorm has own dining, recreation, study rooms. 83,000 s.f
location_description: North side of west Sixth Street between Line and Rayburn, site of the West Sixth
cost_notes: $1,303,000 (Bonds and U.S. Housing and Home finance Agency)

title: Gauss-Johnson Engineering Building and Laboratory
name_history: Originally Kirtley Engineering Lab #1; Kirtley Engineering Laboratory #2
naming_notes: Named for Henry F. Gauss, ME department head 1932-1952. Originally Kirtley Engineering Lab #1; Named for J. Hugo Johnson, EE department head, 1932-1954. Originally Kirtley Engineering Laboratory #2
use_history: Mechanical engineering teaching and research labs, classroom, faculty and grad offices
description: Concrete and brick construction, tile partitions, flat and gable roof, basement and one floor with balcony, 197' x 118' 27,029 sq. ft.; Reinforced concrete, brick veneer, two floors and basement, 155' x 52' 25,025 sq. ft.
location_description: Sixth and Line Streets 620 S. Line St

title: Geology Building
standing_notes: Demolished summer of 1984 to allow for construction of Life Sciences North
use_history: Originally used as an assay building, became instructional building for geology, and between 1955 and 1984 was university museum and art gallery
description: One story, floor area 108' x 36', 5928 sq. ft., reinforced concrete frame, brick facing with rubble foundations, steel roof trusses and wooden roof. Floor plan resembles an 'I'
location_description: S.E. corner Idaho Avenue and Pine Street

title: Gibb Hall (Life Sciences North)
naming_notes: Named for Richard D. Gibb, President of the University from 1977-1989, in November 1993
use_history: Bacteriology/Biochemistry/Biology/ UI Research, teaching and research labs
description: Four story brick and stone construction, 56,000 sq. ft.
location_description: Idaho Ave, between Pine and Ash streets 820 Pine St

title: Golf Course and Clubhouse
naming_notes: In the fall of 1952 was named for Francis L. James, golf coach and designer of the course who had died the previous spring.
use_history: Originally caretakers cottage and James Memorial Clubhouse 1936-1969. In 1969 rebuilt as ASUI Clubhouse.
additions: Club house wing added in 1948, previously was caretakers cottage
architect: Clin, Smull Hamill, Shaw and Assoc. (Boise)
description: One story, frame construction, plaster walls, asphalt shingles, concrete foundation
location_description: University golf course
cost_notes: $2,455; additions $30,000. Original cost was by student activities bond fund

title: Greenhouse (First)
use_history: Green house
description: Stone foundation, brick and glass walls, cement floor, iron rafters, 18' x 50'
location_description: East of the old Administration Building near Blake Ave.

title: Greenhouses (1908- )
use_history: Greenhouses (updated and renovations have likely occurred.)
description: Five glass and steel greenhouses
location_description: Idaho Avenue 1104 W. 6th St

title: Gymnasium Annex
use_history: Used for Air Force ROTC and boxing room
description: One story frame construction, wood siding, wood shingles, gable roof, 35' x 150'
location_description: Rayburn Street and Idaho Ave.

title: Hartung Theater
name_history: Originally called Performing Arts Center
naming_notes: Named for Ernest Hartung, President UI 1965-1977
use_history: Constructed between 1972 and 1973; officially opened in April 1974. Theater and related shops
description: Concrete foundation, walls and footings, brick veneer; 21,683 sq. ft.
location_description: Stadium Drive 625 Stadium Dr.

title: Hays Hall
name_history: Hayes Hall; Alumni Office
use_history: Originally Women's dormitory housing 125 girls; Currently Alumni Office, Printing and Design Services, Alumni Residence Center, Arboretum Office
additions: Remodelled 1971 to allow University offices on ground floor and student apartments on upper floors.
architect: David C. Lange M.S., UI architect
description: Five story brick and concrete with full basement, gable roof
location_description: Blake Avenue 1212 Blake Ave
sources: Cards, Morton, Facilities Architecture Drawing Archives

title: Heating Plant

additions: Mainly boilers added in 1939 and 1948
description: Brick and concrete, flat roof of composition roofing, four stories high

title: Human Resources and Procurement Services

name_history: Also called Industrial Arts Building (New)

title: Infirmary (Old)
name_history: Infirmary; Home Management House
use_history: Originally a residence. Connected to Crest Cottage to increase the size of the infirmary. About 1941 became Home Management House
description: Two story, wooden frame construction
location_description: Originally on University on current site of Life Science South, later moved to Ash Street next to Crest Cottage.

title: Janssen Engineering Building
name_history: Janssen Engineering Classroom Building
naming_notes: Named for Allen S. Janssen, Dean, College of Engineering, 1946-1967.
use_history: Engineering administrative offices; classrooms; teaching and research labs; auditorium; video outreach
description: Reinforced concrete with brick veneer; flat roof; basement, ground floor and three additional floors; L-shaped, 45,455 sq. ft.

title: Jenkins Cottage
standing_notes: Torn down when Memorial Gym was built
use_history: Purchased in 1920, used as living accommodations for students
location_description: West of Lewis Court

title: Kibbie Dome
standing_notes: Addition: 1982 (east end), Addition: 2004, Significant Renovation: 2011(Opsis Architecture)
name_history: Also know as the ASUI Activity Center.
naming_notes: Named for alumnus William H. Kibbie who contributed $300,000 toward the facility, and the Associated Students University of Idaho.
use_history: Construction began February 1971, with formal dedication in 1975. Athletic multipurpose facility; athletic department offices
additions: Phase 1. Grandstand, press box and grass infield (1971) Phase 2. Artificial turf and roll up mechanism (1972) Phase 3. Roof and end walls (1975) Phase 4. East End office and multi-use addition (1982); $4.5 million. Renovations: 2010/11, seating and press box upgrades.; Two phase project to improve and satisfy Life Safety and Code requirements. Project self-funded by the University of Idaho through a series of bond finance instruments. (facilities website) Phase 1, 2008/09; $10-million, approved by the Board of Regents, and an additional $2 million from State of Idaho Permanent Building Fund. Phase 2, 2010/11; $11 million, approved by the Board of Regents.
architect: Glen Cline of Cline, Smull, Hamill, & Associates (Boise); Art Troutner (Boise)
description: Arched roof with 400 foot clear span, 18,000 seats. Building is 410' x 498', height is 150'; floor area is 93,550 sq. feet
location_description: Perimeter Drive and Rayburn Street 1000 Stadium Dr.

title: Larch Hall
location_description: Line Street (between Sweet Hall and Navy Building)

title: Law Building
naming_notes: Renamed in 1984 for Albert A. Menard, Professor of Law and Dean Emeritus
use_history: Construction began January 1972, occupied fall 1973 with formal dedication April 1974. Law administrative offices; classrooms; library; faculty offices; study space
description: Basement and 2 floors, brick
location_description: Rayburn Street 711 Rayburn St
sources: Morton, Argonaut, Facilities Architecture Drawing Archives

title: LDS Institute
location_description: 902 Deakin Avenue

title: Library
use_history: Book collection, research space, campus branch of U.S. Post Office, 1957-1990
additions: 1988 basement was remodeled; $12.3 million, 66,000 sq. ft. addition built in 1991. New tower is 86 ft above ground level
description: Reinforced concrete frame, brick facing, flat roof, basement, ground and three floors 138' x 205', 89,606 sq. ft. Modular construction allows flexibility of interior arrangement
location_description: University Ave. (across from Memorial Gym) 850 Rayburn St

title: Life Sciences (South)
name_history: Science Hall, Life Sciences, Life Sciences South
use_history: Dedicated 1924. Bacteriology/Biochemistry/Biology teaching and research labs; faculty and grad office.
additions: Life Sciences North added in 1986
description: Tudor Gothic, reinforced concrete faced with red brick, roofed with slate. Center section 120' long, east and west wings 69' and 100' respectively, 64,057 sq. ft. Three stories and basement.
location_description: University Avenue, between Ash and Pine Streets 770 University Ave

title: Lindley Hall
name_history: Pine Hall 1963; Vandal Hall 1969-1973
naming_notes: Named for Ernest Hiram Lindley, President of the University 1917-1920. Name changed to Pine Hall in 1963, then Vandal Hall from 1969-1973
use_history: Men's dormitory
additions: Top floor added in 1922
description: Three story, brick, gabled roof with wood shingles
location_description: Ash and Idaho Ave.

title: Lindley Hall Annex
name_history: Alpha Tau Omega, Lindley Hall Annex, Senior Hall, Ridenbaugh Hall Annex
use_history: Was originally home of Alpha Tau Omega fraternity; then senior hall for men during the 1930s. From 1941-1946 known as Ridenbaugh Hall Annex; 1946-1952 Lindley Annex; finally sold to Kappa Kappa Gamma.
description: Three floors, wood frame and siding, gable roof with cedar shingles
location_description: Originally on site of present infirmary, later on south side of Idaho Ave, between Elm and Ash Streets

title: Lionel Hampton Music Building
naming_notes: Renamed in 1987, Lionel Hampton School of Music in honor of Jazz musician Lionel Hampton
use_history: Music classrooms, auditorium, faculty offices, library, rehearsal rooms
architect: Hugh Richardson (Lewiston); General contractor, C.B. Lauch (Boise)
description: Reinforced concrete, brick facing, Gothic style, basement and two floors, gable roof, 80' x 140, 32,937 sq. ft.
location_description: Blake and Sweet Avenue 1010 Blake Avenue

title: Liszt Hall
name_history: Horticulture Building; Music Building, Liszt Hall
use_history: Originally used for horticulture research, then music
additions: Remodeled in 1907 for music department
description: Two story wood frame and siding, 24' x 34'
location_description: Eastern slope of campus, 75 yards east of present Administration Building

title: Living Learning Community
additions: Phase completed Fall 2003
description: Eight residence halls and office/dining structure
location_description: Corner Line Street and Sixth 901 Paradise Creek St

title: MacLean Field
naming_notes: Named for James Alexander MacLean, University of Idaho president, 1900-1913
use_history: Sports
description: Baseball field
location_description: Site of current Education Building and Women's Physical Education Building

title: McClure Hall
naming_notes: Named for James A. McClure, U.I. alumnus and U.S. Representative 1967-1972, U.S. Senator 1973-1990
use_history: Completed 1995. Classrooms, laboratories, offices for school of Mines, also Strategic Resources & Environment Laboratory
description: 4 story, 70,000 sq. ft.
location_description: 7th Street 810 W. 7th St
sources: Register (Aug. 23, 1993), Argonaut, Facilities Architecture Drawing Archives

title: McConnell Hall
name_history: Willis Sweet Hall
naming_notes: Originally named McConnell Hall after William McConnell, university founder, third governor of the state and recipient of first UI honorary degree. In 1984 it was renamed Willis Sweet Hall after Willis Sweet, university founder and Regent, 1889-93
use_history: Single student dormitory for 110 male students, also used as a guest residence, in 1988 became women's quiet dorm
description: 2-story concrete block
location_description: N.E. corner Sixth and Rayburn 1020 W. 6th St
sources: Morton, UG 12 (2279), Argonaut, Facilities Architecture Drawing Archives

title: Memorial Gymnasium
naming_notes: Built as a memorial to Idaho citizens who lost their lives in the 1914-1918 war
use_history: Physical education classes, athletic facilities, campus recreation, ROTC
additions: West end ($281,200) and southeast exit ($35,567) added in 1952; construction on unit 2, the west end, began in the spring of 1951 with Commercial Builders of Moscow serving as contractors; the cost was $261,606. Extensive renovation was completed in 1954
architect: Designed by David C. Lang, University Architect and head Dept. of Architecture, assisted by Theodore Pritchard, construction engineer was A.T. Schenck. Unit 2, Victor N. Jones & Assoc. of Boise
description: Five stories plus tower, concrete and brick construction, tile and plaster walls, 142' x 201'. Tudor-Gothic style, heavily buttressed, especially at the large front bay. Listed on National Register of Historic Places
location_description: University Ave. 1001 University Ave
sources: Cards, UG 44, Beacon, IHS 137, UG 12 (2313), UG 39

title: Mines Building (New)
use_history: College administrative and department offices; teaching and research labs; classrooms, faculty and graduate offices.
architect: Hicks & James, Culler, Gale, Martell, Norrie & Davis (Coeur d'Alene). General contractor Commercial Builders (Moscow)
description: Three stories, 28,275 sq. ft., concrete frame with prestressed concrete T-floor and roof system, curtain wall with multi-colored porcelain enamel panels, concrete masonry interior walls and some brick masonry exterior.
location_description: 7th Street east of Line 825 W. 7th St
cost_notes: $534,199 (one half legislative appropriation, one half private contributions from mining industry

title: Morrill Hall
name_history: Forestry Building
naming_notes: Named for Senator Justin S. Morrill of Vermont who introduced a bill later known as the Morrill Act which provided fee land for the founding of land-grant universities in each state.
use_history: Originally constructed for the College of Agriculture and Agricultural Experiment Station. Became Forestry building in 1950. Currently houses the Idaho Geological Survey, Graduate School offices, classrooms, and Dept. of Philosophy.
additions: Fourth floor added in 1930
description: Four story brick and stone, 65' x 125', 28,246 sq. ft.
location_description: Idaho Ave, N. end of Pine Street 820 Idaho Avenue
sources: Cards, UG 44, Grant Miller, Petersen, Argonaut

title: Moscow Forestry Sciences Laboratory (Rocky Mountain Research Station)
use_history: Building has functioned as the Rocky Mountain Research Station in the area.
location_description: 1221 South Main Street

title: Music Hall Annex
name_history: President's House, Music Hall Annex
use_history: Once served as home of early presidents. Probably acquired in the original land purchase following the founding of the University in 1889.
description: Wood frame, gable, two floors and basement
location_description: Nez Perce west of Bartley Cottage

title: Native American Migrant Education Center
name_history: Entomology Laboratory; Personnel Office, Purchasing Office; Math and Statistics Tutoring Center; Career Services
use_history: Entomology laboratory; personnel and purchasing office; math and statistics tutoring center; career services (2000?- )
architect: Constructed by UI Department of Buildings and Grounds
description: Wooden frame, cedar lap siding and shingles, gable roof, 80' x 40'
location_description: Line and 7th St. 403 Farm Road?

title: Natural Resources Building
use_history: Forestry administrative and department offices, teaching and research labs; classrooms; faculty and grad offices.
location_description: Sixth Street at Line Street

title: Navy Quonset
description: Quonset hut, sheet steel with wood ends, concrete floor, 19' x 51'
location_description: Beside Naval Classroom Building, NW corner

title: Navy/ROTC Building
standing_notes: Demolished after extensive fire damage, Summer 2011
name_history: Navy Classroom Building; Radio Training Center (WWII)
use_history: Originally constructed as a training center for naval radio operators during WW II. Has been used by ROTC since.
additions: Damaged by arson fire May 6, 1970, repaired at a cost of $22,000.
description: One floor, wood frame and siding, gable roof, 60' x 165'
location_description: Line Street 685 S. Line St

title: Neale Stadium
standing_notes: Destroyed by arson fire, November 23, 1969; Condemned 1968.
naming_notes: Named for Mervin G. Neale, University President, 1930-1937
use_history: Athletic contests
description: Football field
location_description: West end of campus (Current Kibbie Dome area)
cost_notes: Wood bleachers and press box on north and south of field, $47,770 (Student activities bond fund) 1936.

title: Niccolls Home Economics Building
name_history: Home Economics Building, Niccolls Home Economics Building
naming_notes: Named for Mary Hall Niccolls, alumni who provided significant funding for Home Economics scholarships
use_history: Classrooms and offices, University A-V classroom
additions: Addition on east side for elevator in 198-
description: Four story collegiate Gothic, brick veneer over reinforced concrete and steel, partially ornamented front. 26,424 sq. feet
location_description: South of quadrangle, (on site of old Engineering Building) west of Ridenbaugh Hall 751 Campus Dr.

title: North Campus Center (Idaho Inn)
name_history: Originally Cavanaugh's motel
use_history: Remodelled 1992, occupied 1993. Studio apartments for graduate students, meeting rooms, information center. Now the Idaho Inn hotel.
location_description: 645 West Pullman Road
cost_notes: $1.1 million purchase price, $2,4 million for remodelling

title: Park Village (original)
standing_notes: Newer construction of 1 bedroom units on site
use_history: Faculty housing
description: Pre-fabricated housing units, 28 1,2,3 bedroom units, one floor, four units to a building
location_description: Line and Third Streets

title: Park Village Apartments (Second)
use_history: Married and graduate student housing
description: 8 two-story apartment buildings
location_description: Third and Home streets

title: Parking Office and Information Center (Former)
use_history: Campus information; parking control, university switchboard; currently Campus police substation. For present parking offices see: Transportation Center
description: One story, triangular shape, glass on two sides
location_description: Line and Third Street 880 W 3rd St

title: Pea Weevil Research Laboratory
name_history: Pea Weevil Research Laboratory, Industrial Arts Building,
use_history: Combined with Forestry Laboratory in new location. Then Industrial Arts Building.
description: One story wood frame and concrete, gable roof
location_description: Originally east of Forestry Laboratory on Urquhart. Moved in 1950 to Sixth Street to make room for Engineering Building

title: Physical Education Building (PEB)
name_history: First called Women's Health Education Building
use_history: Completed January 1970. Athletic facilities; department offices; faculty and grad offices
architect: Fulton Gale of Culler, Gale, Martell (Coeur d'Alene); General contractor Sceva Construction Co. (Spokane)
location_description: South of Memorial Gym and Swim Center

title: Pine Hall
standing_notes: West half torn down in 1955 or 1956; Demolished in 1960
name_history: Also known as Hudson House Dorm
use_history: Dormitory for 386 men
description: Pre-fabricated, wood frame, composition roof, two stories, flat roof
location_description: Warehouse Drive (west of Line, and South of Third)

title: Pine Hall Cafeteria
use_history: Cafeteria, later used for storage; Central Receiving
description: Quonset hut, sheet metal, one story, 99' x 102'
location_description: Line Street

title: President's House
standing_notes: Originally built in 1966, remodeled extensively down to the foundation in 2019 by Nat J. Adams & Associates. (Boise)
name_history: Executive residence
use_history: Official residence of University President; UI reception space
description: Split level, Basque wood carvings on front door
location_description: 1026 Nez Perce

title: President's Residence (Old)
use_history: Official residence of University president
description: Wood frame and siding, basement and two floors
location_description: 514 East First Street

title: Radio-Isotopes Laboratory
use_history: Formerly Wood Conversion Laboratory, originally located at Line Street and Urquhart, moved in 1950 to allow building of Engineering Building
description: One floor, wood frame and siding, gable roof, Wood shingles, 29' x 118'
location_description: Line Street between 3rd and 6th Streets
sources: Cards, Maps, Facilities Architecture Drawing Archives

title: Radio-TV Center
name_history: Radio-TV Center; Temporary Classroom Building 3; Radio Center
use_history: Production and broadcasting center; Originally temporary building #3; converted to Radio Center in 1949
additions: 1968 addition replaced TCB 3
description: 2 buildings; Original building was one floor, wood frame, gable roof, composition shingles, wood siding, painted white, 25' x 76'
location_description: SW of Administration Building
sources: Morton, Argonaut, Facilities Architecture Drawing Archives, Cards, Maps

title: Renfrew Building
name_history: Originally the Physical Sciences Building
naming_notes: In October 1985 it was named for Malcom Renfrew, professor and inventor.
use_history: Chemistry/Physics department offices; teaching and research labs; Chemstores; faculty and grad office; labs and classrooms are of modular design.
additions: $3.3 million renovation in 1991; additional renovation 1998
architect: Dropping, Kelley, Finch (Boise); major contractor, Commercial Builders (Moscow)
description: Rectangular reinforced concrete foundation, reinforced concrete post and beam construction, 96,430.
location_description: Rayburn Street

title: Ridenbaugh Hall
naming_notes: Named for Mary E. Ridenbaugh, vice-president of the Board of Regents, and regent from 1901 to 1907
use_history: Was first women's dormitory and site of domestic science classes, then in 1927 was men's dormitory. Later used as music practice rooms, and currently also houses the Art and Architecture gallery
description: Brick, gabled, three floors, 78' x 96', 15,712 sq. ft. Set on a native basalt foundation, this blocky red brick building rises three stories and is topped with a truncated hip roof. Listed on National Register of Historic Places
location_description: South side of quadrangle, corner of Blake and Nez Perce
sources: Cards, Morton, UG 44, IHS 141, Beacon, Facilities Architecture Drawing Archives

title: Safety Office
use_history: Engineering research labs, office, Engineering Isotopes Laboratory
architect: Constructed by UI Department of Buildings and Grounds (Larry Chin, UI architect)
location_description: 6th Street west of Greenhouses 1240 W. 6th St

title: SATC Mess Hall
use_history: Eating area for Student Army Training Corps
description: Temporary building in the shape of an "H", each company having its own wing, with kitchen facilities in the bar of the H
location_description: NW corner of Administration Building auditorium wing

title: Shoup Hall
name_history: School of Communication; Air Force ROTC (1999)
naming_notes: Named after George L. Shoup, last territorial governor and first state governor.
use_history: Single student dormitory for 110 students
additions: Elevator added 1999?
architect: Dropping, Kelley, Finch (Boise); Contractors: Henry George & Sons and Dunham Contracting
location_description: N.W. corner 6th Street and Rayburn Streets

title: Small Animals Laboratory
name_history: Small Animals Laboratory; Media Center
use_history: Small animal research; currently AV, photocopying, etc.
additions: Remodeled for Media Center in 1986 when Life Sciences North was completed
description: Constructed entirely of reinforced concrete, two floors, flat roof
location_description: Idaho Avenue, adjacent to University Classroom Center
sources: Cards, Morton, UG12 Bx80 F2276, Facilities Architecture Drawing Archives

title: South Hill Homes (original)
standing_notes: Torn down to make room for family housing
use_history: Faculty housing
description: Pre-fabricated four and five room houses, one floor, no basement. 25 units, 20 two bedroom, 5 three bedroom
location_description: Deakin and Taylor Avenues
sources: Beacon, Inventories, Facilities Architecture Drawing Archives

title: South Hill Terrace Apartments
naming_notes: Name probably taken from South Hill Homes which were on the site previously
use_history: 8 units in 1970; 10 units in 1972. Married student and family housing
additions: Several additions to complex
description: Pre-fabricated 2 bedroom 2 story units, 8 apartments to a unit
location_description: Blake and Taylor Streets

title: South Hill Vista
use_history: Units constructed 1992, occupied 1993. Family housing for students, day care center (Early Childhood Center)
description: 108 one and two bedroom units
location_description: South side of Sweet Ave.
sources: Register (5:29), Argonaut, Facilities Architecture Drawing Archives

title: St. Augustine's Catholic Center
use_history: Religious services
architect: Paul Blanton and Theodore Pritchard (UI professors)
description: Circular chapel with 84 foot diameter, 72 ft. conical roof covered with cedar shake shingles, walls are poured concrete. Student center is 2 story rectangular structure
location_description: Deakin and Sixth St.

title: Steel House
use_history: Delta Chi Fraternity House
location_description: Steel House, originally at Blake House, moved to the Phi Kappa Tau fraternity house from 2009-12. Then to the former Delta Chi house.

title: Storage Buildings
use_history: Built 1910-1911; acquired 1923. Constructed in 1911 for $100,000 by Harvester Company. Used as agriculture engineering shops, then as storage area for Veterans Village after World War II.
description: Three buildings, 1 story concrete and factory glass, on 6 acres of land.
location_description: West Sixth Street near Line

title: Student Health
name_history: Infirmary, Student Health Center
use_history: University hospital with 68 beds, and student health center; WAMI offices.
additions: A $385,000 addition, with alterations to the existing structure which doubled the space in the infirmary was begin in 1958
architect: Whitehouse & Price (Spokane); Construction by Colonial Construction of Spokane; Architects for addition were Wayland & Cline (Boise) General Contractor: Dunham Brothers
description: Reinforced concrete with brick veneer, three stories plus finished basement. College Gothic style, with stone trim and shingle tile roof. Outside walls are of terra cotta tile and brick, trimmed with Indiana limestone. 194' x 54'
location_description: University Ave. and Ash Street 832 Ash St

title: Student Recreation Center
location_description: Line Street

title: Student Union Building
name_history: Student Union Building
use_history: In 1936 the Board of Regents purchased the Blue Bucket Inn, owned by Dean of Women Permeal French, and used for some time for student activities. Several additions and renovations followed. Student support and food and recreation services
additions: Unit #2 (1936) $250,000, concrete, brick veneer with cut stone trim; Unit #3 (1948); Unit #4 (19560, $1,800,000. 1961 addition, 1962 remodel, 1963 bookstore addition; 2000 renovation
description: Reinforced concrete with brick veneer, three floors and basement
location_description: Deakin Street

title: Student Union Building Annex
name_history: Alpha Chi Omega, 1924-1960; Elm Street house, 1960-1962; Theta Chi fraternity, 1962-1987; Student Union Building Annex, 1987-
use_history: Originally fraternities, then used by Air Force ROTC
location_description: 7th and Elm streets

title: Swimming Center
use_history: Swimming instruction, recreation, and competition
description: Total area 33,839 sq. ft.; two pools 60 x 75 x 4 and 60 x 75 x 6, underwater viewing windows
location_description: South of Memorial Gym

title: Targhee Hall
name_history: Originally Campus Club
naming_notes: Most likely named for a chief of the Bannock tribe who was killed by Crow Indians in 1871. Properly spelled Tygee, later Tige, then Targhee.
use_history: Men's co-op dorm. Originally Campus Club, built to replace the original Campus Club which burned Wednesday May 14, 1958.
architect: Hicks, James & Culler, Gale, Martell & Norrie of Coeur d'Alene; General contractor: Albert & Leffler; Builder: Commercial Builders (Moscow)
description: Reinforced concrete frame, brick facing, 2 story dormitory to accommodate 60 students, single story lounge, dining and kitchen area adjacent. Basement for recreation area, utilities and storage under a portion of the dormitory wing.
location_description: NW corner of Blake and Taylor streets
cost_notes: 190,000 (Board of Regents borrowed $95,000, the rest was from unallocated funds)

title: Teaching and Learning Center
name_history: Previously University Classroom Building
use_history: Construction began in 2003; completed Fall 2005.. 29 classrooms, a computer teaching lab, two digital teaching labs, the Office of the Dean of Students, study areas, cyber cafe.
description: Originally constructed in 1965. Designed by Fulton Gale Jr. of Culler, Gale, Martell, Norrie & Davis, remodeled significantly in 2005 by Opsis Architecture.
location_description: 966 University Avenue

title: Temporary Classroom Building 1
standing_notes: Dismantled to allow construction of Education Building
use_history: Department of Psychology located in building until 1952. Then used by Counseling center, Sociology, Anthropology, and Dramatics storage.
description: One story, frame, wooden, 51' x 75', gable roof, composition shingles, wood siding, painted white
location_description: NW of Administration Building

title: Temporary Classroom Building 2
standing_notes: Torn down August 1966, replaced by College of Education in 1965
use_history: Used for classrooms and Letters and Sciences offices.
description: Prefabricated, one floor, frame, gable, composition shingles, wood shakes, painted white, 25' x 300'
location_description: West of Administration Building

title: Temporary Classroom Building 4
name_history: Called Communication Laboratory from 1947-1951
description: One story frame structure with cedar lap siding and cedar shingles, 152' x 40'
location_description: SW of Engineering Testing Laboratory

title: Theophilus Tower
name_history: Forney Hall, 2nd & 3rd floors; French Hall, 4th and 5th floors; Hays Hall, 6th & 7th floors; Sweet Hall, 8th & 9th floors; Chrisman Hall, 10th & 11th floors
naming_notes: Named for Donald R. Theophilus, U.I. President 1954-1965.
use_history: Construction began Nov. 1967, completed Sept. 1969. Single student dorm, co-ed.
description: 11 story building with accommodations for 416 students; 90,779 sq. ft.
location_description: Paradise Creek Street

title: Transportation Center
location_description: NE corner of Railroad and Sweet
sources: Sources UI Transportation website; Design West company website

title: Triangle Club
name_history: Infirmary; Senior Hall; Triangle club; Home Management House; Lindley Hall Annex; Tau Kappa Epsilon
use_history: Two old frame houses, formerly the Infirmary and Senior Hall were consolidated into the Triangle Club on a cooperative basis. In fall 1938 one became the Home Management House, the second became Lindley Hall Annex. The third rented to Tau Kappa Epsilon
description: Wood frame houses
location_description: Ash Street

title: UI Advancement Building
name_history: Home Management House (New); U of I Foundation and Development Office
use_history: Home Economics labs; faculty and grad offices; 199- University of Idaho Foundation offices
description: 2 level, open plan, brick exterior
location_description: Nez Perce Street

title: University Classroom Center
name_history: University Classroom Center
use_history: Constructed in 1964, occupied in 1965; remodeled as Teaching and Learning Center 2003-2004. General classrooms; student support offices; media/photo center
architect: Designed by UI graduate Fulton Gale, Jr. of Culler, Gale, Martell, Norrie & Davis (Coeur d'Alene
description: Brick and concrete; 77,259 sq. ft.; ramps connect the levels, all room have doors opening to the outside.
location_description: University Ave across mall from Library

title: University Garages
description: One story brick; 20 buildings
location_description: NE of heating plant; West of Buildings and Grounds Center

title: University Hut (U-Hut)
name_history: Y-Hut, Post Office, U-Hut
use_history: Initially called the Y-Hut, built by the National War Work Council of YMCA and intended for student soldiers. Used by English Department, campus theatre group, and theatre department for dramatic productions.  Post office substation operated in the building from 1926-1957. Briefly housed ASUI and Art Department offices. Black box theatre renamed Collette Theatre for professor and department chair Jean Collette. Final use was as Idaho Commons construction headquarters.
architect: Upgraded by UI Department of Buildings and Grounds after purchase
description: One story frame structure, gable roof, wood shingles and siding, basement, 50' x 90'
location_description: University Avenue and Line Street
sources: Cards, Morton, Facilities Architecture Drawing Archives

title: Veterinary Science
description: One floor, wood frame and siding, gable room, basement, painted white, 25' x 75'
location_description: S.W. Sixth and Rayburn Streets

title: Wallace Complex
naming_notes: Named for William H. Wallace, first territorial governor of Idaho, 1863-1864
use_history: First two units and cafeteria completed in 1963. Single student dorms and cafeteria; also student services offices.
additions: Third unit completed August 1965; 4th unit completed July 1967
description: Central structure with four wings; central portion is 2 floors and contains cafeteria and offices. The two south wings are 4 floors and house 212 students each. The north two wings are 6 floors and house 312 each.
location_description: NE corner 6th Street and Greenhouse
cost_notes: First two units and cafeteria $3,750,000; 3rd unit, $1,536,000; 4th unit budget $1,502,000

title: West Sixth and North Main Villages
standing_notes: Condemned and closed in fall of 1958 due to fire risks; Torn down fall 1959
use_history: Housing for veterans and married students
additions: 74 cinder block buildings added November & December 1956.
description: War surplus barracks style units moved in from Portland containing 156 apartments.
location_description: Sixth St. west of Line; North Main & D Street

title: Women's Center
name_history: University Classroom Building; Journalism Building; Women's Center, Tutoring and Academic Assistance Center
use_history: Classrooms; Women's Center and student academic assistance
architect: Constructed by UI Department of Buildings and Grounds
description: One floor, wood frame with cedar lap siding, gable roof, 40' x 120'
location_description: Line Street and Idaho Avenue

title: Wood Conversion Laboratory
standing_notes: Demolished prior to construction of Engineering Building
architect: Constructed by UI Department of Buildings and Grounds
description: Concrete floor, wood frame, 30' x 25'
location_description: Line and 7th Street

title: Integrated Research and Innovation Center
description: 3.5-story, rectangular-form structure with curtain wall fenestration on the east faade. Red-metal cladding, glass, and red-brick masonry combine to create a visual link to surrounding buildings. The structure rests on a reinforced concrete foundation built into the hillside and includes balconies on the second and third floors, concrete staircases, and glass-and-metal doors. LEED Gold certified.
location_description: 685 Line St
